content:
The Act titled "Department of Transportation Bonding Assistance Authority Act of 2009" allows the Secretary to guarantee surety against loss from a principal's breach of bond. The Secretary is authorized to guarantee surety against loss resulting from a breach of bid, payment, performance bonds, or ancillary bonds by a principal, subject to prescribed terms and conditions. The Secretary can guarantee surety against loss from a breach of bid, payment, performance bonds, or ancillary bonds by a principal, with limitations on eligibility and necessity for bidding on a contract. The Secretary can guarantee surety against loss from a breach of bid, payment, performance bonds, or ancillary bonds by a principal if the person is an eligible small business concern, the bond is necessary for bidding on a contract, the person cannot obtain the bond without a guarantee, and there is a reasonable expectation. The Secretary can guarantee surety for small businesses unable to obtain necessary bonds without a guarantee, ensuring performance of contract covenants under reasonable terms. The Secretary may agree to indemnify a surety against losses resulting from avoiding breach in connection with issuing a guarantee for small businesses unable to obtain necessary bonds without a guarantee. The Secretary may agree to indemnify a surety against losses from avoiding breach in connection with issuing a guarantee for small businesses. The Secretary may agree to indemnify a surety against losses in avoiding a breach of a bond guaranteed by the Secretary, subject to certain conditions. The Secretary may approve payments by a surety to avoid a bond breach, with a limit of 10 percent of the contract price unless a greater payment is deemed necessary due to the surety's loss. The Secretary may approve payments by a surety to avoid a bond breach, limited to 10 percent of the contract price unless a greater payment is justified by the surety's necessary and reasonable loss. The Secretary cannot pay the surety an amount exceeding the guaranteed share of the bond available to them. The Secretary can approve payments by a surety to prevent a bond breach, up to 10 percent of the contract price or a higher amount if justified by the surety's necessary loss. The Secretary cannot pay the surety more than their guaranteed share of the bond. The reimbursement to the surety is limited to 90 percent of the loss incurred and paid by the surety. The Secretary can reimburse the surety for up to 90 percent of the loss incurred and paid by the surety under the guarantee or agreement. The Secretary can reimburse the surety for up to 90 percent of the loss incurred under the guarantee, except in cases of fraud or misrepresentation. The Secretary can be relieved of liability if the surety obtained the guarantee by fraud, breached terms, or violated regulations. The Secretary may be relieved of liability if the surety breaches a material term, violates regulations, or engages in fraud. Regulations set standards for sureties in underwriting, claims, and loss ratios. The Secretary may establish regulations for participating sureties regarding underwriting, claim practices, and loss ratios. The Secretary may also adopt a procedure for reimbursing sureties for paid losses and require reports and audits. The Secretary may require participating sureties to report to them regularly and may conduct audits at any time. The Secretary may require participating sureties to make reports and conduct audits as needed. Audits may be done at the offices of the surety every three years. The Secretary may require participating sureties to make reports, conduct audits every three years, and establish fees for small business concerns and premiums for sureties. The Secretary may establish fees for small business concerns and premiums for sureties under this subsection, with up to 5 States participating in a program. The Secretary may establish a program for up to 5 States to carry out activities related to issuing guarantees and assisting small business concerns with a portion of the funds appropriated for this subsection. The Secretary may establish a program for up to 5 States to issue guarantees and assist small business concerns with appropriated funds. States selected must meet prescribed assessments and standards. States selected for the program must meet assessments and standards set by the Secretary. Participating states must submit annual reports detailing their program, guarantees provided, and eligible participants. States selected for the program must meet assessments and standards set by the Secretary. Participating states must submit annual reports describing their program, guarantees provided, and eligible participants to the Secretary. The Secretary will then submit an annual report to specific committees in the House of Representatives. The Secretary will submit an annual report to specific committees in the House of Representatives detailing the implementation of the program, the number of sureties receiving guarantees, and the states involved. The Secretary will submit an annual report to specific committees in the House of Representatives detailing the implementation of the program, the number of sureties receiving guarantees, the states involved, and the participation of eligible small business concerns. The Secretary will submit an annual report to specific committees in the House of Representatives detailing the implementation of the program, the number of sureties receiving guarantees, the states involved, and the participation of eligible small business concerns. Additionally, the report will include information on the number of States managing amounts under the program, States approved to participate, and the results achieved by participating States. Definitions for this subsection are also provided. The curr_chunk discusses the definitions of "bid bond" and "eligible small business concern" in relation to a program established under paragraph (8). It clarifies the terms used in the program. The curr_chunk defines "bid bond" as a bond required for bidders on a contract, and "eligible small business concern" as a small business owned and controlled by disadvantaged individuals. An eligible small business concern is defined as a small business owned and controlled by socially and economically disadvantaged individuals or service-disabled veterans. An eligible small business concern can be owned and controlled by service-disabled veterans, women, or qualify as a HUBZone small business. A qualified HUBZone small business concern, a small business concern owned and controlled by women, and an obligee defined as the person requesting bids for a contract. The term 'obligee' is defined as the person who has contracted with a principal for the completion of a contract and to whom the obligation of the surety runs in the event of a breach. The term 'payment bond' refers to a bond ensuring the principal's payment to contracted persons. Surety runs in the event of a breach by the principal of the conditions of a payment bond or performance bond. A payment bond is for the principal to pay contracted persons, while a performance bond is for the completion of a contract according to its terms. The terms in the curr_chunk define key roles in contracts: performance bond ensures contract completion, prime contractor is the main contractor, and principal is the party bidding or subcontracting. The term 'contractor' refers to the person contracted to perform the contract. The term 'principal' includes prime contractors bidding for contracts or those primarily responsible for completing a contract or making payments. The term 'contractor' refers to the person contracted to perform the contract, while the term 'principal' includes prime contractors primarily responsible for completing a contract or making payments. The term 'Secretary' refers to the Secretary of Transportation. The term 'surety' refers to the person or State bound under the terms of a payment or performance bond. The Secretary of Transportation is defined as the 'Secretary', and a 'subcontractor' is a person contracted to perform a contract under a prime contractor. The term 'subcontractor' refers to a person contracted by a prime contractor or another subcontractor to perform a contract. A 'surety' is a person or State that guarantees payment or performance under a bid or performance bond. A bid bond guarantees payment to the obligee if the principal breaches the bond. A performance bond covers the cost of fulfilling a contract if the principal breaches it. A payment bond ensures payment to all parties involved. A payment bond ensures payment to all parties supplying labor and material in the event the principal fails to make prompt payment. The curr_chunk discusses the authorization of appropriations to the Secretary for carrying out activities under a specific subsection, with a specified amount for each fiscal year. The Secretary is authorized to appropriate $50,000,000 annually for activities under a specific subsection, with a limit of $20,000,000 for certain activities. SEC. 3. NATIONAL INFORMATION CLEARINGHOUSE.

Amends Section 332(b)(1) of title 49, United States Code to include "any Federal, State, or local mode of transportation".

SEC. 4. PROVISION OF RELEVANT INFORMATION.
